instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC’s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message:
Seems no liquid damage. But USB-C to magsafe converter were used before it is dead.

where to start?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message: Use 60/85W Magsafe 1 charger and post some basic voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message:
I am using 85w. I noticed there is some corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR>. <RESISTOR>R5301</RESISTOR> went missing and the traces going to pin 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> is broken/corroded.

Checked Pin 4 is still connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.48v until fan is stopped...

I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and also re-solder 100k between pin 4 and pin 5, it is still the same...

<TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> pin 3 is 12.48v until fan stop and cycling.   

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses 3.3v

L7510/20 = pulse 1.14v

L7550 =  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG_L</SIGNAL> = 0v. 

<TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR> pin 1 pulse 12.6v, [B]pin 4 = <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> pin 12 = shorted to ground.[/B]

<CHIP>U7400</CHIP> voltage; pins 15,24,40 = pulse 5v, pin 1 = pulse 3.3v , pin 2 = pulses all over the place.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message: tried to remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR> and the pin 4 pad seems no short but when replaced another <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR>, the short come back.. is this a short?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message: <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> is bad, if has short to ground at pin 4.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message:
Short on pin4 of <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, or <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR>?
If on <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR>, what is ohm value of the short?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR> pin 4 is connected to <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> pin 12, when both are on the board, they seems to be shorted to ground(9 ohm). L7550 = 0V when on power.

with <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR> removed, the pin 4 solder pad have no short and when measure voltage it pulses.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message:
CPU coils may have very low resistance to ground as normal.
You can compare eith good board.
I suppose you don't have any short there.

Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?
Just in case, replace <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> and check its traces and solder to pin 2/<CHIP>U7400</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> is good and its traces and solder to pin 2/<CHIP>U7400</CHIP> are good too.

SMC bypass mode = fan stay on, USB storage has LED on too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message:
What is CPU voltage after 10s?
Did you try more DDR3 memory modules?

If machines stays on in SMC bypass, then you have problems with a SMC sensor.
Check first <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message:
L7510/20 = 0.9v after 10s. L7550 = 0.44v at that time.

machine did stay on in SMC bypass, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> = 3.3v even when the fan stopped spinning..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message:
VCORE should drop around 0.75V when board really boots.

In SMC bypass the fan should spin continuosly to max speed.

Take a look at the circuitries from pages 49 & 50.
Your starting problem is related with one I/V sensor.
Check their output voltage in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_CPU_VSENSE</SIGNAL> = 0.65 - 0.95 fluctuate
<SIGNAL>SMC_CPU_ISENSE</SIGNAL> =0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_GFX_VSENSE</SIGNAL> = bouncing 0 - 0.7v
<SIGNAL>SMC_GFX_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>TP_SMC_P1V5S3_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 0.27v
<SIGNAL>SMC_CPUVCCIO_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>TP_SMC_SA_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = unknown test point location
<SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_VSENSE</SIGNAL> = 2.82v
<SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_ISENSE</SIGNAL> = 2.1v and when lifting multimeter it will shut down

I will measure the rest later today but is anyone of the above look suspicious so far?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message: Check resistance (ohm scale) between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message:
"17/18 = 20 ohm"
You should get 2 ohm aprox there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message:
ya i know from schematics <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> + <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> + <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> should be 2.21ohm..

let me get a new multimeter, as now it is measuring 10.x ohm..

There is a glue blob around <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> but I saw brownish shadow within it near <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> pin2 .. when I cut open the glue blob I confirmed that pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> was probably heated up somehow that causes burn mark on the surrounding glue.. now <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> measured around 7.9 ohm between pin 1 and pin 2. <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> measured around 3.0 ohm (however between the 2 pole or any 2 screws the multimeter read 0.9ohm, assuming this is internal resistance between the 2 pole). I guess subtracting that from 3.0 will give 2.1 ohm which means <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> is probably OK.

I measured <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> and it is also 0.9 ohm. again subtracting the internal resistance should be 0 ohm, which also means <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> is ok.

This implies <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> is messed up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan turn on and off cycling, no orange LED when connected to battery
threads.message: Replaced <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> and it is all good now. Thanks for the help.
